ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Halfway through the class, the course transitioned from a virtual biology lab to a class on geospatial information systems. So it was half virtual lab and half virtual seminar? I'm still quite confused about what happened with this class.
Zoom lectures live each Friday from 1:30-5:30pm EST
N/A
there were also asynchronous components, like lab videos and additional virtual discussions in our project groups
in person seminar only.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about enzymes, bacteria transformations, methods to prepare samples for analysis, how to use EndNote, and how to make graphs with GraphPad Prism. I learned about GIS and how to make maps, dashboards, and storymaps with ESRI.
Learned some methods in biology lab and how to analyze their data, learned how to use GIS. Learned how to use EndNote.
Basic experimental design, how to write a lab report, data analysis. Some workshops on using Endnote, Prism, ArcGIS.
Learned how to analyze data sets and use tools such as graphpad prism, arcgis online, etc.
In-depth practice with the scientific method, thinking through scientific procedures, bacterial transformation, central dogma, writing lab reports, ArcGIS map-making
This course taught me the basics of writing research reports as well as how to use ArcGIS to map out geospatial relationships and display data.
I learned how to use ArcGIS, EndNote, and Prism to create well-written lab reports.
I developed critical thinking skills.

I learned about setting up experiments in biology labs and the different considerations that entails. In addition, I learned about the formatting of biology research and the presentation / generation of representative figures and graphs.
We learned some common bio lab techniques, how to write lab reports, and how to use ArcGIS software.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: not too many assignments, doable workload, kind Professor and TAs, collaborative 
Weakness: Zoom lectures were kind of long and tiring

This course covered some of the classic experiments in biology labs decently well. The lab reports were quite annoying though, as expectations and instructions said different things each time, and points were deducted oftentimes with little explanation or reason.

Strengths: Dr. Moreno is very kind and cares about her students and their feedback. She went out of her way to give us a good lab experience, calling in people from the university library and from ESRI to work with us and give workshops. Weaknesses: The course didn't seem very well-adapted for online learning. Lab sessions were very long and it was just very difficult to learn about laboratory techniques without actually being in the lab. Additionally, I didn't feel that the expectations were very clearly communicated (especially since we weren't given any rubric for the lab reports, just some written guidelines which would change as the semester progressed).

Strengths: introduced me to a lot of useful technology that I think will help me in future research (learning to use graphpad prism, write a lab report, etc)

Weaknesses: lab sessions were very long and virtual, so it could be hard to focus at times

The course is taught by a great lab instructor, Professor Moreno. Thinking through the different lab procedures was very helpful for writing the lab reports. This class is also very collaborative, which was great over online instruction.

I really enjoyed the ArcGIS project, it was a highlight that could potentially be kept for future semesters. However, the main weakness of the class was that it was held as a virtual lab, which got to be quite draining. Lab report criteria were also not very well explained, so sometimes it can be difficult to know what exactly is expected for us to complete. Lab reports were also very long and detailed, though Dr. Moreno offers generous extensions to make the deadlines more accomodating.

A strength of the course was Dr. Moreno. She was intentional about assignments and made sure to incorporate skill-building activities to the best of ability in a virtual setting by teaching students to graph with Prism, cite with EndNote, and map with ArcGIS. Nonetheless, we still had a classic introductory lab experience by looking at and documenting enzyme quantification, how the Lac Operon works, etc. Our in-class discussions forced students to consider how to strategically perform an experiment to compensate for the online nature of the course. Dr. Moreno was clear, interesting, and extremely kind and flexible with students due to the unprecedented learning situation.
The course went over concepts in great detail. However, it was hard to get a feel for the actual techniques.

I really appreciated all the hard work and preparation Dr. Moreno put into making the course work remotely. Sometimes pre-lab lectures were quite long and difficult to focus on, as we were unable to use the machines/settings she discussed, which we normally would have been able to use in person. In general, the lab course was quite long, especially over zoom. In addition, it was a little frustrating to receive feedback from the two different TF's, who would focus on different criticisms of lab reports, docking points where the previous TF didn't  this made it difficult to understand what elements to have in lab reports across both TF's.

Prof. Moreno really cares about her students and is also good at explaining the lab techniques. I thought the three lab reports were a strength. We got to learn Prism and had chances to improve our reports with each one. Learning GIS was also a strength, I never would have done so without this class. A weakness was that 4 hours is a really long time to be on Zoom and I struggled to stay alert and focused, especially during the GIS lectures near the end.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The first few weeks when we went over labs for 4 hours without breaks while being cold-called by the professor were not fun or enjoyable. A number of things we covered in lecture were already in the reports we were given to read beforehand, so a lot of times it was hard to focus. The second half of the course worked better when we learned to use GIS and worked with groups. Being able to interact with peers in breakout rooms really helped liven up the course.
I appreciated the change in the middle of the course from learning lab techniques (which was difficult to do online) to actually doing a project.
The focus on tools that could be learned virtually, rather than simply reading about many labs, was very helpful.
Working in groups over breakout rooms was successful for student learning. I think this course was overall very well organized for learning during the pandemic.

I really appreciate all the effort Dr. Moreno put into the class to adjust the lab to a virtual format, however, I believe that the class would benefit from more asynchronous components outside of class so that we would not have to be on the Zoom call for 4 hours straight. This would allow us to be more engaged during classtime where we would discuss the more challenging aspects of the lab without having to also run through lab procedures which could be done prior to class.

Virtual engagement was facilitated by the platforms Dr. Moreno taught us how to use such as ArcGIS, the workshop leaders she invited, and the setup of her discussions that prioritized synthesis/planning of experimental steps.
Shorter labs and lab lectures would be great! I'm not sure how to improve a biology lab over zoom, when bio labs rely on learning in-person wet-lab techniques.

Teaching GIS was a success. I learned a skill I would not otherwise have. However, I thought the lab reports worked too. While we didn't learn how to actually collect the data, I thought we had thorough instruction on how to analyze it and write a lab report about it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: not bad if you need a biology lab
Yes, this is a great bio lab if youre pre-med.

I can't in good faith recommend this class to another student. I'm not sure if I can accurately evaluate this class because of the great shifts in course content. Half of the class was a geospatial data and information class having nothing to do with biology. Logistics-wise, the class was 4 hours on Zoom with no scheduled breaks, which was exhausting and tormenting. I do not feel that I am leaving this course with the advertised biology lab skills, so I cannot recommend this class.

Good luck, friends. This course was not particularly challenging, but was quite mentally taxing. If you're new to bio lab techniques, this may be helpful to you. Also if you're looking to explore wet lab research in biology, this could be a good overview for you. Also I guess if you're new to scientific writing.

Dr. Moreno is a great professor who truly cares about her students and their learning. However, I hesitate to recommend this course as it was this past semester. Overall I think this is a course that would be much better in-person -- it was difficult to learn lab techniques just by reading about them, and sitting in a zoom session for 4 hours every Friday afternoon was also very tiring. There was also no rubric or guideline provided for the final project and it felt like expectations for grading were generally unclear. This class is not that much work (only 3 lab reports and a final project), so if you really don't like writing, this lab could be a good way to get 0.5 writing credits. I did gain some useful skills using new programs, and overall I'm happy to have finished the MCDB lab requirement this semester with this lab.
Yes, but it would be much better done in-person!

Yes, I highly recommend this course to other students, especially if you want to learn how to write lab reports well and if you want to learn about carrying out successful experiments. It gives a great foundation for students of all years for scientific procedures and experiments.

If this class occurred outside of COVID, I may have recommended this class to another student. However, given the virtual lab format, the first half of the class was devoted to conducting virtual labs synchronously, which I feel was not a great approximation of the lab experience we would have received.
Yes, especially if one is interested in building their critical thinking skills.
Yes. It will probably be in a different format, but I learned more usable skills in this class than in lectures. (Prism, writing reports, GIS)
